Wording: 10. What are the [q2o1answer] speakers' attitudes towards linguistic transfers from [q2o2answer], such as lexical or grammatical borrowing?
Comment: Hard to assess. A great number of loanwords came from Sicilian, both in high and low registers (administration, law, taxation, religion, but also construction, handcrafts, manufactured goods). In addition to loanwords, Sicilian influenced the vowel system of Maltese, and to a lesser extent morphosyntactic features (overview in Brincat 2021: 103–143). There was no clear language policy to promote the use of Sicilian (or to substitute the use of Maltese with Sicilian), but the linguistic transfer spread through "persistent process which was a peaceful one because if followed material and social progress" (Brincat 2021: 116) – I'm interpreting from this that the attitudes were at least "open", even if "positive" might not be exactly the right term.

Wording: 18. Typically, how many levels of jurisdictional hierarchy are there in the [q2o1answer] speaking society, beyond the local community?
Comment: In our time frame, Malta is part of County of Sicily, later Kingdom of Sicily, governed by foreign powers (Normans in 11–12th c., Swabians and Angevins in 13th c., Aragonese in 13–14th c., and Habsburg Spain from 1480 until the French took over in 1714). In 1530, Malta was given as a fief to the Order or St. John by Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor and King of Spain. (Blouet 1967; Mack Smith 1968; Said-Zammit 2016; Brincat 2021). Malta had local jurisdictional/political organizations, including a council (università) that discussed issues pertaining to Malta. This council was also in contact with Sicily. (Blouet 1967: 45–46; Brincat 2021: 77–78; Said-Zammit 2016: 40) However, major political decisions were done by the foreign rulers and aristocracy. The catholic church was also an institution with major jurisdictional power, occasionally clashing with the Order over jurisdictional authority (Blouet 1967: 45–46, 89, 154–155; Said-Zammit 2016: 37–78). During the rule of the Order of St John, the municipal councils lost their power and the Order established a more centralised administration (Blouet 1967: 56; Said-Zammit 2016: 59). Thus, in our timeframe, there is some variation. I chose 'four levels': including the municipal level, the level of foreign aristocracy/royal representatives, level of the Kingdom of Sicily (administered by Viceroy of Sicily) and the level above that, i.e. the foreign heads of state (e.g. Charles V, King of Spain).

Wording: 19. Typically, how many levels of jurisdictional hierarchy are there in [q2o2answer] society, beyond the local community?
Comment: As stated above (CID OS1), Sicily was governed by foreign powers; first the Normans (11–12th c.), Swabians and Angevins (13th c.), then as an independent kingdom by the Aragonese (13–14th c.), and lastly Habsburg Spain (from 1480 until the French took over in 1714) (Mack Smith 1968; Brincat 2021) and Malta was administratively a part of Sicily. Since 1530, Malta was governed by The Order of St. John, while Sicily remained part of the Spanish kingdom. During the Spanish rule, Sicily had a parliament, modelled after the Aragonese custom (Mack Smith 1968: 124–132), and the Viceroy was above the jurisdictional power of the parliament (ibid.: 128–129). The catholic church was also an organization with major jurisdictional power.

Wording: 5. Traded good types. Do [q2o1answer] people trade raw materials and primary produce to [q2o2answer] people?
Comment: Maltese traded at least cotton (Borg 2012: 1035; Cassar 2002: 13, Said-Zammit 2016: 51, 71, Blouet 1967: 130–132) and meat products (Said-Zammit 2016: 51) to Sicily. Sicilian wheat (Blouet 1967: 144; Brincat 2021: 131; Borg 2012: 1035; Cassar 2002: 6–9, 19; Mack Smith 1968: 136–137, Said-Zammit 2016: 62) and wine (Zaid-Sammit 2016: 51) were imported to Malta. Brincat (2021: 212, 219) describes the Maltese society pre-1500 as being mostly focused on agriculture and fishing. Skilled craftsmen arrived from Sicily to Malta, Brincat (2021: 238) also mentions the passing on of new techniques, along with the terminology, from immigrant craftsmen to apprentices/assistant. Cassar (2002: 11) describes Malta as a "society which depended heavily on transactions of low value and bulky commodities". Based on this, I doubt that the Maltese traded luxury items or manufactured goods to Sicilians. Various documents (receipts, taxation) imply that manufactured and luxury goods (Brincat 2021: 77 mentions e.g. cartj 'paper', Jnchensu 'incence') were sold in Malta, and as the names of these objects are in Sicilian, I'm suspecting that Maltese acquired these from Sicilians. Sicily also produced silk and sugar cane (Mack Smith 1968: 58), and exported e.g. sulphur, saltpetre, ostrich feathers (ibid.: 91. NB! Not necessarily traded to Malta), and other European products made their way to Malta mainly through Sicilian ports (Blouet 1967: 135).
